column4: Hey guys, I installed UNR 10.10 on my netbook but I can't figure out how to connect to the internet through my wireless router. I've been trying since yesterday but the OS just won't show me the wireless networks. It's becoming urgent I get connected and would appreciate some help.
Can anyone at all help me out?

Hey guys, I installed UNR 10.10 on my netbook but I can't figure out how to connect to the internet through my wireless router. I've been trying since yesterday but the OS just won't show me the wireless networks. It's becoming urgent I get connected and would appreciate some help.
does the 'addational drivers' tool suggest any other drivers for your wireless?
I'll try to find that additional drivers thing. I'm entirely new to Linux.

When I click on the little ubuntu icon on the top left then search for additional drivers, I see two tools. One which's icon is a chip and a lock in front of it, the other which is a box with a ruler and other stuff in it.
i dont use the netbook edition. so not sure what you are refering to.
open terminal and run 'gksudo jockey-gtk' perhaps. :)
I did that, it prompted me for my pass which I put in and I got: Downloading package indexes failed, please check your network status. Most drivers will not be available.
i would connect a wired cable.. and let it check again. yoru wireless card may need addational drivers.
Is it okay if I stay here to inform you of progress?
as long as you are going to run a cable.. do a update/upgrade also.
Ive not had to mess with wireless in ages.. so  You got most all tehinfo ui ahve on the topic. :) otheres in here may be able to help with other issues that come up.
I plugged in an ethernet cable. I'm now connected to the internet.
Do I try gksudo jockey-gtk again?
yes.
I did, it did some updating or something. Now it popped up an issue about there being no proprietary drivers in use on this system with "Broadcom STA wireless driver">
if you are lucky thats all you needed.
What would have been the manual equivalent to typing gksudo jockey-gtk in terminal?
system -> admin -> addational drivers.
That fixed it!! Thank you so much!
